rename.from: [ENH] should we adopt defensive upper version bounds?
rename.to: [MNT] should we adopt defensive upper version bounds?

issue.title: [BUG] AutoARIMA fit breaks with sktime 0.8.0, sklearn 1.0, pmdarima 1.8.2

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what the bug is.
-->

**To Reproduce**
<!--
Add a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example (for more details, see e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import statsmodels.api as sm
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.forecasting.arima import AutoARIMA

df = sm.datasets.macrodata.load_pandas()['data']
df['q_date'] = df.apply(lambda x: str(int(x['year'])) + '-Q' + str(int(x['quarter'])), axis=1)
df['date'] = pd.PeriodIndex(df['q_date'], freq='Q').to_timestamp()
df = df.set_index('date').to_period("Q")

y = df['realgdp']
y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=30)
forecaster = AutoARIMA(sp=4)
forecaster.fit(y_train)
```

Error:
```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
~\AppData\Local\Temp/ipykernel_22920/2308042316.py in <module>
     13 y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=30)
     14 forecaster = AutoARIMA(sp=4)
---> 15 forecaster.fit(y_train)

~\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\_base.py in fit(self, y, X, fh)
    178         #####################################################
    179 
--> 180         self._fit(y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh)
    181 
    182         # this should happen last

~\AppData\Roaming\Python\Python38\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\adapters\_pmdarima.py in _fit(self, y, X, fh, **fit_params)
     47         """
     48         self._forecaster = self._instantiate_model()
---> 49         self._forecaster.fit(y, X=X, **fit_params)
     50         return self
     51 

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\auto.py in fit(self, y, X, **fit_args)
    175         # Temporary shim until we remove `exogenous` support completely
    176         X, fit_kwargs = pm_compat.get_X(X, **fit_args)
--> 177         self.model_ = auto_arima(
    178             y,
    179             X=X,

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\auto.py in auto_arima(y, X, start_p, d, start_q, max_p, max_d, max_q, start_P, D, start_Q, max_P, max_D, max_Q, max_order, m, seasonal, stationary, information_criterion, alpha, test, seasonal_test, stepwise, n_jobs, start_params, trend, method, maxiter, offset_test_args, seasonal_test_args, suppress_warnings, error_action, trace, random, random_state, n_fits, return_valid_fits, out_of_sample_size, scoring, scoring_args, with_intercept, sarimax_kwargs, **fit_args)
    715         )
    716 
--> 717     sorted_res = search.solve()
    718     return _return_wrapper(sorted_res, return_valid_fits, start, trace)
    719 

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\_auto_solvers.py in solve(self)
    284 
    285         # fit a baseline p, d, q model
--> 286         self._do_fit((p, d, q), (P, D, Q, m))
    287 
    288         # null model with possible constant

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\_auto_solvers.py in _do_fit(self, order, seasonal_order, constant)
    231             self.k += 1
    232 
--> 233             fit, fit_time, new_ic = self._fit_arima(
    234                 order=order,
    235                 seasonal_order=seasonal_order,

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\_auto_solvers.py in _fit_candidate_model(y, X, order, seasonal_order, start_params, trend, method, maxiter, fit_params, suppress_warnings, trace, error_action, out_of_sample_size, scoring, scoring_args, with_intercept, information_criterion, **kwargs)
    528         # check the roots of the new model, and set IC to inf if the
    529         # roots are near non-invertible
--> 530         ic = _root_test(fit, ic, trace)
    531 
    532     # log the model fit

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\pmdarima\arima\_auto_solvers.py in _root_test(model, ic, trace)
     36 
     37     if p + P > 0:
---> 38         max_invroot = max(0, *np.abs(1 / model.arroots()))
     39     if q + Q > 0 and np.isfinite(ic):
     40         max_invroot = max(0, *np.abs(1 / model.maroots()))

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\metaestimators.py in __get__(self, obj, owner)
    107             # delegate only on instances, not the classes.
    108             # this is to allow access to the docstrings.
--> 109             if not self.check(obj):
    110                 raise attr_err
    111 

~\anaconda3\envs\skt080\lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\metaestimators.py in _check(self, obj)
    195             return False
    196         # raise original AttributeError
--> 197         return getattr(delegate, self.attribute_name) or True
    198

ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()
```

**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->
This code works in version 0.7.0 and would return the fitted ARIMA model.

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->

    python: 3.8.11 (default, Aug  6 2021, 09:57:55) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
executable: C:\Users\szipk\anaconda3\envs\skt080\python.exe
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.19042-SP0

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.0.1
   setuptools: 58.0.4
      sklearn: 1.0
       sktime: 0.8.0
  statsmodels: 0.13.0
        numpy: 1.19.5
        scipy: 1.5.4
       Cython: 0.29.14
       pandas: 1.3.3

       joblib: 1.1.0
        numba: 0.54.1
     pmdarima: 1.8.2
      tsfresh: 0.18.0
</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body:
Another report on the same thing apparently happening with `sklearn`'s recent 1.0 upgrade here #1503, causing an issue via `pmdarima`.

I think we really should adopt devensive upper bounds or it may cause low reliability of `sktime`.

rename.from: [MNT] should we adopt defensive upper version bounds?
rename.to: [MNT] we need to adopt defensive upper version bounds on package dependencies

rename.from: [MNT] we need to adopt defensive upper version bounds on package dependencies
rename.to: [MNT] adopt defensive upper version bounds on package dependencies

issue.title: [BUG] pmdarima 2.0.0 incompatibility - return indices

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Soft dependency `pmdarima` 2.0.0 was released a few hours ago, and it seems to break our `ARIMA` interface.

Suspicion: return indices are now absolute and no longer relative to the cutoff.

body:
One more data point - we had a near miss with `pandas` 1.5.0 that would have shot apart one of our most important estimators, `Lag`, plus a few other smaller issues, related to `freq` stuff. It looks like this came without clear warning.

Because we had a defensive version bound `<1.5.0`, this did not propagate through to `sktime` in deployment.

To me, looks like a point in favour.

I would suggest a policy where we keep defensive version bounds as long as we can react within a few weeks. As long as testing indicates, for a given dependency, that `sktime` would have broken, we should keep those bounds (say, until three times in a row of MINOR updates without issues?)

issue.title: [BUG] testing deep learning base class fails due to optimizer type

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

 test_deep_estimator_full[keras-adamax] is failing due to a type check in keras. See, for example

https://github.com/sktime/sktime/actions/runs/3495913658/jobs/5855642783

"ValueError: `optimizer` of type <class 'keras.optimizers.optimizer_v2.adamax.Adamax'> cannot be serialized, it should either be absent/None/str/tf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer object"

it could be that the wrong type of Optimizer is being used, output states

Optimizer  = <class 'keras.optimizers.optimizer_experimental.optimizer.Optimizer'>
whereas it is expecting
tf.keras.optimizers.Optimizer

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/202723857-05d98e12-f03b-40e5-a4ac-97405b330638.png)

I don't want to hack around in the testing suite, I'll let someone who understands it better do that,

body:
@lmmentel, I wanted to show someone the discussion we had on this, e.g., that adopting too strict devensive bounds or even pins may lead to packages getting out of sync or resulting in contradictory requirements.

Not sure where that was - would appreciate a pointer, or a summary of your opinion here, in case it was only on slack.

@achieveordie in #3816:

> Of course, one can argue that our build should hold more specific versions as said by @RikStarmans, but I'm not sure what would be the "right" approach. On one hand, the current code enables us to catch and correct such changes while on the other we'd ensure the test suite works without fail.

These considerations, and earlier instances of "update results in failure" have made me open this issue, and prompted us to introduce some defensive version bounds on core packages.

The situation and trade-off is, however, not as straightforward as it may seem.
Unfortunately it may be that the discussion we had internally was not recorded properly, or I'm just failing at finding it.

The main counterargument is as above: you introduce too many pins or bounds, then it becomes more and more difficult to find *any* working configuration if you are installing many packages - the argument is by the Kantian imperative, "suppose everyone was doing this, what would happen"?

You could now argue, ok, frameworks are more "top-level" than component packages, but people can also opt to install multiple frameworks, which may have incompatible dependency bounds.
(It really looks like I'm having a monologue with myself here, but there was a very heated discussion on our internal slack and in dev meetings, as said, it may not have been recorded)
